stories.title: Erika Kobayashi on Growing Up in a Household of Sherlock Translators

stories.text:
Hello HN,

Years ago, I came across a website about JavaScript weirdness.

It was structured as a list of exercices with an example of output and you had to come up with the snippet of code to produce that output.

There was stuff like:

  > x === x
  false
  // solution was x = NaN
Or:

  > a == b && b == c && a != c
  true
I can't find the website anymore, I'm wondering if someone here remembers it.
stories.title: Ask HN: Help me find this website that I should have bookmarked
Blot is a blogging platform with no interface. It turns a folder into a website
I Am Easy To Find (short film, 2019)
Ask HN: What productive things do you do on your phone in place of social media?
Next.js Adventures: Some Blasphemy Against the Holy Image Component

stories.text: I have multiple Apple devices with Siri enabled on all of them. But I don't know why we can't ask Siri on any specific device to activate itself. Whenever I say "Hey Siri", it activates on a random device. For example, at my Mac, it opens Siri on my iPhone which is farther away. It should be fairly easy to implement a feature that activates Siri on any specific device. Or am I missing something?
stories.title: Ask HN: Why does “Hey Siri on my iPhone” activate Siri on my iPad?
